channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-3165] Regression in assignment of single character strings to char array element
item.description:
There has been a regression in 1.6 that causes the assignment of a String with length 1 to a char location to fail if it is an array element.

So where as these still work:

char c
c = 'a'
c = '\u00A0'

these don't (and are fine in 1.5.x):

char[] ca = new char[1]
ca[0] = 'a'
ca[0] = '\u00A0'
item.summary: Regression in assignment of single character strings to char array element

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Patch to add test case. Not in SVN yet cause I hate to break the build...
Test case committed to 1.5.x branch.
Looks like an unintended regression to me.

Attaching patches that fix the reported issue on branches 1.6-RC-1, 1.7-beta-1.

Made a small change in org\codehaus\groovy\runtime\dgmimpl\arrays\CharacterArrayPutAtMetaMethod (
on the same lines as DefaultGroovyMethods[public static Character putAt(char[], int, Object)])

Hope it helps.
Roshan

Well, this is really Jochen's issue I think, but he seems busy and your patch prompted me to try it out.

In looking at the invoke method and the fix, I recognized that GString then would be a problem, and indeed it is (turns out to be a bug that exists in 1.5.x too so isn't a regression in that case).

Then I see that the return value from these putAt methods is null and therefore can't be used as the value of the assignment expression. Sure enough that leads to anomalies when we're doing the coercion here. So it seems the right level for doing the coercion should be at a higher level, but when I try to apply what would be the right fix which is changing PARAM_CLASS_ARR to say CHARACTER rather than OBJECT as in:

{{
private static final CachedClass CHARACTER_CLASS = ReflectionCache.getCachedClass(Character.class);
private static final CachedClass ARR_CLASS = ReflectionCache.getCachedClass(char[].class);
private static final CachedClass [] PARAM_CLASS_ARR = new CachedClass[]

{INTEGER_CLASS, CHARACTER_CLASS}

;

public CharacterArrayPutAtMetaMethod()

{ parameterTypes = PARAM_CLASS_ARR; }

public final CachedClass getDeclaringClass()

{ return ARR_CLASS; }

public Object invoke(Object object, Object[] args)

{ final char[] objects = (char[]) object; final int index = normaliseIndex(((Integer) args[0]).intValue(), objects.length); objects[index] = ((Character) args[1]).charValue(); return null; }

}}

that doesn't work:

{{
No signature of method: [C.putAt() is applicable for argument types: (java.lang.Integer, java.lang.String) values:

{0, a}

groovy.lang.MissingMethodException: No signature of method: [C.putAt() is applicable for argument types: (java.lang.Integer, java.lang.String) values: {0, a}

at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.ScriptBytecodeAdapter.unwrap(ScriptBytecodeAdapter.java:54)
at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.callsite.PojoMetaClassSite.call(PojoMetaClassSite.java:40)
at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.callsite.CallSiteArray.defaultCall(CallSiteArray.java:43)
at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.callsite.AbstractCallSite.call(AbstractCallSite.java:116)
at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.callsite.AbstractCallSite.call(AbstractCallSite.java:128)
at groovy.ArrayTest.testCharArrayAssignToElement(ArrayTest.groovy:35)
}}

So I've applied your patch (with a little tweaking) to the trunk as an interim solution, but there looks to be further problems here and Jochen is the guy to deal with it.

Interesting. Yes, I notice now that DGM's "putAt(char[] array..." used to return the Character object whereas CharacterArrayPutAtMetaMethod.invoke(..) does return null. but it wasn't mentioned in the JIRA details anywhere, so I worked only on the exception reported.

Anyway, the return value difference is there for all the data-type extensions of ArrayPutAtMetaMethod(and not only for character data-type) and it may have to be looked at from a higher level of problem solving.

In the meanwhile, if the DGM implementations and ArrayPutAtMetaMethod extension implementations remain as similar as possible, it should be helpful from the point of view of not breaking what used to work with earlier versions.
if we can't produce code that breaks because of this difference, then we should assume that it does not break.. anyone here tried to find code that would be broken by this?

A serious problem for me is that the semantics are surprising and hard to justify from a language perspective. More compelling for others perhaps is the inconsistency. If we don't return the char value assigned to the array element, then this fails:

def foo = 'z'
char c
char[] ca = new char[1]

def v1 = (c = "$foo")
def v2 = (ca[0] = "$foo")

foo = 'X'

assert (v1 == v2)

Hmm, actually (v1 == v2) fails because of the GString not being evaluated. And this succeeds even though I thought GString behavior was such that it would fail:

assert (v1.toString() == v2.toString())

Anyhow, this fails which certainly gets into the corner case but reflects the trouble with the semantics and lack of consistency:

assert (v1.class == v2.class)

And this problem isn't just for char[], but also Character[] and String[].

And what about numbers?

I don't have time to dig into this problem. How about you Roshan? You're getting into some nitty-gritty stuff.

It is very important IMHO that assignment to array elements works identically to assignment to variables and fields. If we were ever to have a language spec, there is no way it would be otherwise.

Doing the conversion inside the putAt is not going to work if the result is going to be ignored by the caller. Either the caller needs to use the result of the putAt or the putAt needs to specify the type of the value so the caller can do the conversion.

As you note in GROOVY-3167 (and as I suspected without having to look), this problem is not only with string stuff but also numbers where we do conversion on assignment.

I will be happy to look into it but I need to know how the behavior should be. Previous comments have not settled whether putAt assignment should return the value or not.

Since returning the "put" value has changed between 1.5.x and 1.6, I wanted to know if it was done for a reason, or it was an oversight and it should be fixed. Unless it is clear, I don't know on what lines to proceed on digging into this issue.

My conclusion is that this is simply a bug. The changes came about as part of new compiler stuff going for speed (call site and friends). But we still need correctness. If Jochen wants to debate further the need to fix this, that is fine with me, but the only argument I can see for not fixing it is that it will take some work. The current behavior certainly is not defensible from a language perspective.

This issue has also revealed there are still some buggy cases in 1.5, and those should be fixed as well, but it looks as though that just involves patching the putAt methods from what I've seen.
Here's a test case (diff to trunk) that I think shows the desired behavior.

if you do def a = (x=y), then IMHO the y gets the value y too and the result of the assignment itself is ignored, because the compiler transforms this. If that is the case, then def a = (x[0]=y) should behave the same way. So for all that matters putAt could be void too. but since the method is directly called and not via reflection we need alignment with reflection, meaning that it can't be void for now. void methods return null when used through reflection, so null is the right value I guess.

that means these putAt method returning null is ok

Ok. So, the return value of the putAt() call is not really making any difference as far as semantics is
concerned because compiler is making sure that in a call like ca[1] = (ca[0] = 'a'), both ca[1] and ca[0]
get the value 'a'.

It should not really be read as ca[1] = <return value of putAt for index 0>.

Compiler is making sure that there are 2 putAt calls that are made and both 0 and 1 index get the value as expected.

def char[] ca = new char[2]
ca[1] = (ca[0] = 'a')
assert ca[0] == 'a'
assert ca[1] == 'a'

So, what really is the "double assignment" kind of code that was fine with 1.5.x and was breaking
when putAt started returning null?
no, simply the test case. 'a' is in Groovy not a char, but a String of length 1. At the same time all Strings of length 1 should be seen as char too. That is broken and needs a fix
the patch does fix that, so I guess applying it and closing this issue is the thing to do now
looks like Jim applied the patch already. Jim if you added the test case too, then we could close the issu
Before the issue can be closed, shouldn't the patch be applied on 1.6-RC-1 too? Currently I see that it is applied only on trunk whereas the issue was found on both trunk and 1.6.
I tried merging revision 14138 into 1.6, but strangely the build then just stops working... it is not failing it tests for ever.
ok, megre successful this time

The problem with char[] simply was the first case I happened to encounter with my application. It is a symptom of array assignment being wrong for any where the element type is such that Groovy may do an implicit conversion. That means char[], Character[], and String[] because of string conversions and pretty much any Number type.

So the issue now is more generally stated that assignment to array elements is inconsistent with assignment to fields and variables.

These should all be true but are not (the new test case checks this for Character[]):

Integer x

Integer[] X = new Integer[1]

def t = (x = 1.0)
def T = (X[0] = 1.0)

assert (x.is(t))
assert (X[0].is(T))

Character y
Character[] Y = new Character[1]

def v = (y = 'a')
def V = (Y[0] = 'a')

assert (y.is(v))
assert (Y[0].is(V)
I don't agree that this is even close to closed...
Added Integer[] case to test along with Character[].

Jim, may I suggest to open a new issue? Because the the problem of this issue has been solved and the other problems are different. They may have a common root, but they are not the same. So I think doing a fresh issue is the way to go instead of keeping this open for fixing unrelated things.

May I add that I think so too. Because different comments seem to be bringing new things in the scope of this issue that were earlier not mentioned anywhere.

It started with just char[] not handling String(1) assignments and then there was some discussion around "double" assignments(def v2 = (ca[0] = "a")) and now it is talking about implicit conversion for other types as a general issue.

This way, it is like an ongoing thing with scope changing every few comments.
A new issue as Jochen requested.
meaning we can close this one, or not?

It depends on GROOVY-3173, so to resolve (not close) it requires resolving the parent issue.

It could be resolved as "duplicate" if you like.

Since this particular issue (assignment of single character strings to char array element) has been fixed (with changes done on 1.6.x and trunk for it) and GROOVY-3173 remains open to cover the remaining regression issues related to assignment to array elements, I am marking this particular JIRA as fixed.
